Linguists have described rules for generating Gapping, though none of them has made any effort to formulate a rule for detecting Gapping. is the first who suggested a rule for Gapping.
The formalisation of the rule is due to (Hankamer 73): Gap pl ng NP X AZ and NP X B Z --> NP X AZ and NP B where A and B are nonidentical major constituents*.
(Sag 76) pointed out that there were cases where the left peripheral in the right conjunct might be a non-NP, as in At our house, we play poker, and at Betsy's house, bridge.

It should be noted that the two NPs in the Gapping rule must not be the same, otherwise would be derived from (6): When processing (8), we treat it as a simplex containing a compound object ("Bill and Mary") functioning as a unit ("unit interpretation"), although as a rule we treat sentence containing conjunction as derived from a "complex", a sentence consisting of more than one clause, in this case "Bob saw Bill and Bob saw Mary" ("sentence coordination interpretation").

The reason for analysing (8) as a simplex is first, for the purpose of translation, unit interpretation is adequate (the ambiguity, if any, will be "transferred" to the target language); secondly, it is easier to process.
Another fact worth noticing is that in the above Gapping rule, B in the second conjunct could be anything, but not empty.
